title.narrative: Activities that ensure media professionals operate with greater awareness of safety and are better protected against threats

1.1 Safety Training Needs Assessment - 25 organisational needs assessments conducted
1.2 Journalist Safety Training (Online Course) - A minimum of 100 participants gain certification Evidence of increased awareness and skills related to physical safety and mental well-being after specific training for editors and journalists
1.3 Digital Safety Training (Online Course) - A minimum of 100 participants gain certification Evidence of increased awareness and skills related to digital safety and mental well-being after specific training for editors and journalists
1.4 Newsroom Safety Management Training - A minimum of 25 participants gain certification and receive mentoring Evidence that newsroom leaders are sensitised to risk management and mitigation techniques after relevant training
1.5 Safety Officers - Up to 25 Safety Officer positions are created or strengthened Evidence of the application and/or development of safety-related standard operating procedures
1.6 PPE Evidence of the

target.value: A substantial number of journalists and media managers are sensitised to issues regarding safety and have acquired or updated their skills as a result of training. Organisational capacity to mitigate risk is improving
Participating media professionals have a better understanding of physical and digital safety and how to manage risk. Media organisations are applying relevant SOPs and embrace a culture of safety

title.narrative: Active support networks amongst media professionals

2.1 Advocacy and Networking Initiatives - 9 in-country networks established and/or strengthened via Media Freedom Committee / Women In News frameworks - 1 regional network established Evidence of new or strengthened professional networks
2.2 In-country and/or regional actions, campaigns or activities to defend media freedom - At least 27 coordinated media freedom actions, campaigns or activities Evidence of coordination to defend media freedom in the face of opposition, or address specific business or editorial challenges

target.value: Up to 250 journalists and media managers are developing or have acquired skills and techniques to better advocate for media freedom; media are working together on issues of common concern

There is a clearer understanding of the importance of media freedom amongst the profession. Media are networked to better defend and advocate against threats to media freedom, and address professional challenges

title.narrative: Activities to address the needs of media aimed at improving skills, tools and management capacities to produce socially impactful reporting

3.1 Editorial and Business Needs Assessment - 25 organisational needs assessments conducted
3.2 Editorial and Business Training - 9 in-country training programmes developed based on needs assessment Evidence of relevant training in response to needs identified
3.3 Danish & International In-House Mentoring - Up to 50 mentoring sessions delivered Evidence of relevant mentoring in response to needs identified
3.4 Social Impact Reporting Initiative - 50 Social Impact Reporting Initiative grants awarded

target.value: Up to 250 journalists and media managers receive/are scheduled to receive training to enhance skills and techniques across editorial and business operations. Grant scheme ensures continued public interest reporting on critical issues
Significant improvement in editorial and business capacity within media organisations. Increased range of public interest reporting
